1 Numbered and unnumbered headings 1.1 Numbered headings Numbered headings can be turned on using numbered_sections: true Unnumbered headings Headings can be unnumbered by adding the attribute - or .unnumbered to them. E.g. # heading {-} This makes use of pandoc markdow header attributes extension. 1.2 headings in table of contents Unnumbered headings will still appear in the table of contents.

2 Table of contents In the YAML we can put toc: true or configure the toc depending on the template. For example the gitbook template has a floating side toc enabled by default. output: bookdown::gitbook: default using html_document2 we can create the same output: bookdown::html_document2: toc: true toc_float: true if we omit toc_float we get a large one page book with a toc at the start.

3 Citations Reference items in your bibliography file(s) using (key?). In the index.Rmd file, in the YAML pass the .bib files to the bibliography key. In this YAML there are a few options to style your citations. For example when we write R Markdown [@xie2015] We get: R Markdown (Xie 2015) Bibliography

7 Mathematical formulas and expressions bookdown uses MathJax for LaTeX style math expressions. Using the same labels we already saw we can number and reference these aswell. We can do this inline between two $ $:\(f(k) = {n \choose k} p^{k} (1-p)^{n-k}\) Or on a new paragraph using double $$ $$: \[f(k) = {n \choose k} p^{k} (1-p)^{n-k}\] We can also use environments: \begin{equation} f\left(k\right) = \binom{n}{k} p^k\left(1-p\right)^{n-k} (\#eq:binom) \end{equation} It renders the equation below: \[\begin{equation} f\left(k\right)=\binom{n}{k}p^k\left(1-p\right)^{n-k} \tag{7.1} \end{equation}\] You may refer to it using \@ref(eq:binom), e.g., see Equation (7.1).
